author: T Madhavan
text:
Those living along Adyar say shifting would affect their livelihoods

The residents may be shifted to a spot 21 km away from their homes —Photo: Special Arrangement

Over 200 residents staged a protest against a proposal by the Kancheepuram District administration to relocate them as part of the drive to remove encroachments along the Adyar river.

The news of officials visiting the place spread like wildfire and residents turned to protest, but none of the officials turned up.

The District administration planned to start the eviction of encroachers from the banks of the Adyar river, which was in spate after erratic rainfall during November-December 2015.

Residents of Stalin Nagar, Quaid-e-Milleth Nagar, Thai Mookambigai Nagar, and Shanti Nagar near Tambaram planned a protest after they heard that they would be relocated to Padappai region, which is 21 kilometres from their locality.

Opposing the resettlement exercise, the residents gathered in front of the village administrative officer’s office in the morning. Police personnel were deployed in large numbers on the spot to prevent any untoward incident.

“We do not accept this decision. Many families will lose their livelihoods. Education of many students will be affected. Many residents have been staying in this locality for over 40 years after acquiring property,” said Shanti, a resident.

“Several of us are going for jobs as helpers at industrial units in Pallavaram and Nagalkeni and many of the women depend on the income from housekeeping jobs. We cannot afford to lose this income. We have asked the officials to reconstruct new houses for us in the same locality. We cannot shift to any area that is far away from this place,” she said.

The protesting residents were pacified by revenue and police officials, who asked them to give a petition to the District Collector.
title: Residents protest move to relocate them to Padappai
